div.p: THE Miſtaken Beauty, OR THE LYAR A COMEDY. ACTED By their MAJESTIES Servants At The ROYAL THEATRE
LONDON Printed for Simon Neale, at the three Pigeons in Bedford-ſtreet in Covent-Garden, over againſt the New Exchange MDCLXXXV.

lg.l: WE had rather have you Auditors to day,
Than only bare ſpectators of our Play,
And exerciſe your Wits as well as Eyes,
The propereſt entertainment of the wiſe.
Mean time our Prologue to our Play to fit,
We'll ſay, it's dull, inſipid, void of wit;
Lame, and deficient much, in every part,
Writ without judgment, plotted without art;
In fine, ſtark naught: but ſtay I lye, and they,
Muſt do ſo to, who diſcommend the Play.

list.item: Dorant his Son and Lucretia's Gallant.
Alcippe, Friend to Dorant, and Lucretia's Lover.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: IN fine, I'm turn'd Gallant, and according to my deſire my Father is content I ſhould throw off the gown and leave the Law with al • its Quirks and Quillits: and now we're in the Thuilleries here, th • Land o'th better World and Gallantry; tell me Clyton, how do'ſt thou like this Metamorphoſis, have I not quite put off the Scholar? who come from the Kingdome of the Codes like me have ſeldome the Meen and Air of Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: That General Rule Sir was not made for you, y'ave nothing of the Scholar in you, nor was Bartolus ever painted a this faſhion; you look as you would make a Thouſand jealous, and I forſee a grand misfortune hanging over the heads of many a married Man; and how d'ye like Paris?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Air is pleaſant and agreeable; and now methinks that Law was too ſevere, under pretence of ſtudy, baniſht me ſo long from hence. But tell me thou who haſt had the happineſs to have liv'd here all this while, and knoweſt all their Divertiſments, How ſhould one gain the Ladies favours?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I marry Sir! I like you, That, as the Poet ſings, is the Gentle Care of every Noble breaſt. But leaving Poets and Poetry, your ſtomach's up betimes I ſee, and your humor can't away with idleneſſe, you long to be doing, you came to Town but yeſter night and to day y'ar ſeeking a Miſtriſs; but I'm in a good poſture and fine Reputation with ye am I not? that you ſhould ask inſtructions of me, as if I were ſuperintendant of the Ladies quarters, and profeſt Maſter of the Faculty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Miſtake not Clyton I mean honeſty and wou'd only be acquainted with ſome of them to talk and be merry for my divertiſement, and pleaſantly paſſe away an hour or two ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I underſtand, and know y'ar no ways given to Deboſherie,

l.hi: And wo'd ſcorn thoſe VVho'd follow you,
At ſound or tinkling of a Crown or two;

sp.p:
nor do you much care; for thoſe ſage Cocquetts confine their ſecret favours all
to Talk, and all your pleaſure to the eyes, the paſtime's not worth the Candle—'tis not to paſs, but caſt on's Time away for Gallants to converſe with ſuch as they—no, no—y're of another Complexion I know; and would be glad with all your heart to meet with ſome of thoſe Good vertuous Ladies; whoſe vertues, upon a good occaſion, are not Incompatible with a little Vice, and you ſhall find of all ſorts here—mean Time what need you ask inſtructions of me! If I be'nt deceiv'd in Phyſognomy, you are no Novice, nor did the Law regulate your time ſo wholly to be always found with a Law-Book in your hand.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To confeſs the Truth Clyton I liv'd at Poictiers as other young Students do and had my ſhare of all their pleaſure too, but Paris and Poictiers are quite different, and as their Climate, ſo their manner of living is quite different too, I have known ſome there counted great Wits for admiring things, which here they would be laugh'd at for, and counted men o'th other World for their admiring them. I'th Country on's glad of any thing and Fools paſs muſter for want of wiſer men: but here, where their eyes are not dazled with thoſe falſe lights, 'tis requiſite they have other qualities; and 'midſt the number of ſo many eminent men on's ill look'd on, if he don't reſemble them.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: You don't know Paris yet I ſee, that's a great Mart or Fair, where you ſhall find inſtall'd all ſorts of Ware, and there is ſuch deceit in them, as one may be as eaſily cozen'd here, as in any part of France: 'tis a great World where 'midſt the confuſion of all ſorts who come from all parts hither, amongſt your choice, as you have every where ſo y'ave at Paris here, your Refuſe Ware, which, being hard to be diſtinguiſhed, moſt commonly every on's eſteem'd according to the rate he ſets on himſelf, and ſo no doubt but they will eſteem you too. But touching your Demand are you Liberal?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm no ways avaritious.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I ask becauſe 'tis a great ſecret in Love, to know how to beſtow on's gifts with diſcretion, otherwiſe you ſhall looſe rather than gain; by it and oblige none by your liberality: the manner of giving's more than the Gift it ſelf, here one in Gaming cunningly▪ diſguiſes his preſents under the name of loſs, another there forgets a Jewel behind him, he knows wou'd ne'r have been accepted had it been preſented; a liberal Fool gives preſents to his Miſtriſs as he were giving Alms; and ſo in doing every thing out of time he diſobliges inſtead of obliging them.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Leaving thoſe Fools thou declaim'ſt againſt, who are theſe Ladies canſt tell?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Alas Sir Ideal in no ſuch coſtly ware, they're too high game for ſuch as I to fly at; but I ſhall eaſily learn of their Coachmen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do'ſt think he'l tell thee?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I, all he knows. And more than you deſire to know to, if he be a right Coachman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ah, She ſtumbles and Dorant lends her his hand

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Lady this miſchance of yours has been a happy chance for me in affording me the occaſion of rendering you this little ſervice.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir the happineſs this occaſion has afforded you is ſo ſmall, y'ave juſt reaſon to count it none at all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: True Lady, I owe it wholly unto chance, nor has your deſires nor my deſerts any part in it, which make me eſteem my ſelf not much more happier than I was before, ſince all the Favour y'ave granted me (in fine) had been denyed to any deſert of mine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I'm of opinion one ſhou'd eſteem a benefit the more, the leſs th've deſerv'd it, ſince a gift is more than a recompence, & conſequently our obligation▪
sp.l: Favour that's merited is in a manner bought,,
Whilſt that we ne'r deſerv'd do's coſt us nought:
And the greateſt happineſs merit can pretend unto,
Is juſt like Hirelings to be paid for what they do,
sp.p: beſides this way we obtain with eaſe, what we cannot without much labour and difficulty, the other.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Think me not Lady ſo preſumptuous to imagine by any merit or deſert of mine to deſerve your leaſt of Favours; I better know to ſet the right value and eſteem on them than ſo, and the leſs I deſerve them count my happineſs the more I know too, how without injury you might have denyed them me; if then my heart repine 'tis only for being ſo unhappy in my happineſs you ſhou'd oblige me without deſign—it is the intention, ſets value on the Act and a kind of undervaluing things
sp.l: To do them without it, the favour then is but ſmall,
To give me y'r hand, 'leſs you give me your Heart withall;
sp.p: and judge how little nouriſhment that fire receives,
sp.l: That Amorous fire inkindled in my breſt,
By giving me your hand and denying me the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
That fire you ſpeak off ſir's ſo new to me as now I only ſee the fireſparks of it; and though your heart perhaps may burn ſo ſoon, yet know
Sir mine requires a longer Time: but now I ſee your flame, mine perhaps may burn hereafter too by ſimpathy; mean time you can't in juſtice blame me not to know what I was wholly ignorant off till now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's the eflect of the misfortune every where perſecutes me, that I ſhould be here e'r ſince I left the German Wars almoſt a year, Night and Day ſeeking the occaſion to make my Love known t'ye now in promenades, and now in Balls, and giving ye ſerenades, and never find that happineſs till now.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And have you been in the German Wars then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have Lady, nor was lightning more impetuous, nor Thunder there more formidable than I.

sp.speaker: Cly,
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Dor,
sp.p: In all which time no Battle e'r was fought, nor Siege e'r laid to any place, but all the Glory of the Victory was principally attributed to me, witneſs the Gazzette—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Why Mr. what mean you? are you mad?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold your peace, or—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: You came but yeſterday from Poictiers, the Devil take me elſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Go to, I ſay—Yes Lady, for that ſhort time I follow'd the Wars I well may glory without vanity, none ere acquir'd a greater name than I.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And how came you to relinquiſh ſo Noble, ſo Gallant an exerciſe?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's the effect only of your fair Eyes, when returning the laſt Winter from the Campania to make my Court at Paris here, ſeeing you Lady, you ſoon made me (in fine) your Priſoner, who had mad many mine, ſince when abanddoning all thoſe noble cares, I formerly imployed in the Wars, Commanding Armies, Conquering Enemies,
sp.l: With Thouſand famous exploits, the Wars now done
I imployed them all in ſerving you alone.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Madame yonder's Alcippe, he'll be jealous.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well Sir, another time we ſhall have leiſure to hear more, now I muſt take my leave,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And will you ſo ſoon deprive me of all my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, notwithſtanding the pleaſure I take to hear my ſelf flatter'd; I muſt needs be gone and make a turn or two in the Walks alone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Grant me permiſſion at leaſt before you go to be your ſervant and always to love you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Who are reſolv'd to Love and know
What belongs to loving too,
sp.p: need ask leave of no body elſe for that beſide themſelves.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do you follow 'em Clyton?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: That needs not Sir; for the Coachman has told me all, the handſomer of the two is his Miſtriſs, ſhe's called Lucretia, ſhe lodges in the place.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What place?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: The place Royal.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Cly,
sp.p: The other whoſe name he does not know is lodg'd there too; I ſhall eaſily find her out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No matter, ſuffices I know the fair Lucretia, the handſomer of the two, ſhe whom I had the happineſs to entertain.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: By Your favour Sir I rather think the other's ſhe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What ſhe who ſtood mute all the while and never ſpoke a word?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Oh Sir, that's ſo rare a quality and perfection in a Woman to hold her peace, ſuch a miracle in nature▪ ſuch a prodgy in Earth, and ſuch a particular grace in Heaven, eſpecially in this Age we live in, as for me who was never married, nor ever am like to be, I ſhou'd prefer one with that quality only, though as ugly and deformed as an old Baboon, to all the perfections of Women-kind; wherefore Maſter ſeek another name for your Miſtriſs if you pleaſe; for infallibility t'others Lucretia, and the handſomer of the two, or I'm an arrant Dunce and blockhead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That I eaſily believe for all thy boutades and flaſhes; but ſee Alcippe my old acquaintance here, by their looks and Actions they ſeem to wonder at ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How! Muſick and Collation upon the Water?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Collation and Muſick.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yeſter night▪

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Yeſter night!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And how?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Magnificent enough.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And who ſhould give it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Nay that I do not know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Dear Friend! how happy am I in this encounter?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And my happineſs is no leſs to encounter you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But I've been unmannerly to interupt your Diſcourſe: pardon my joy in ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You have all power over your Friends Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And of what were you diſcourſing I pray? may I not partake of it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Only of a certain Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Some Love matter I warrant!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I preſume ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What was't? the name of Love and Gallantry has awak'd my longing and curioſity to know it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why we were talking of a Collation and Muſick given to a Lady on the Water.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Good—oft times the Water makes the Fire burn more.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Sometimes it does.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And when was this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yeſter night.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Proper—fires always ſhine brighteſt in the Night; they knew well how to chooſe their time it ſeems: and was the Lady handſome?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Many think her ſo▪

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And the Muſick!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: None of the worſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And Collation!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Excellent well order'd▪

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And don't you know all this while who gave it? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why d'ye laugh?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To ſee you ſo admire a ſorry divertiſment of mine.

sp.speaker: Al,
sp.p: Of yours? Why did you give it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Even I my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And have you got a Miſtriſs already then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I had but ſmall addreſs elſe having been a month or more in Town, though for certain reaſons I ſeldome ſtir'd abroad by Day, and only made
my viſits Incognito by night, not to have got a Miſtriſs all this time.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Why Maſter d'ye know what you ſay?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold your peace, and if ever I catch you interupting me again—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: It makes me mad to hold my peace and hear him lye a this manner.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What luck have You. To have your Rival himſelf, diſcover himſelf unto you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: As to my dear Friends, now I'll tell you all, of five Barges expreſly I had prepar'd, I diſpos'd four Conſorts of Muſick, in four of them; Violins in the firſt, Lutes and Voyces in the ſecond, Flutes in the third, and Hoboy's in the laſt;

l.hi: Who playing by turns ſo Raviſhed our Ears,
It ſeem'd the very Harmony of the Spheres:
The firſt, and moſt capacious of all,
Serv'd us for our Banqueting Houſe, or Hall.
Contrived ſo with interlaced Boughs,
For freſhneſs ſake it ſeem'd a Summer Houſe:
At each corner were Feſtons of Jeſſamine,
With other verdurs, Orange-flowers and Granadine:
Thither I led the Lady I adore;
Attended on, by ſome five Beauties more,

sp.p: and preſently in all pompeous manner the Collation was ſerved in—it were long to tell you the ſeveral Services, Number of the Diſhes, and order of every Meſs: ſuffices it, In this delicious Room, there were ſix ſervices, twelve Diſhes at every one:

l.hi: While the Air, the Water, and adjoyning ſhore,
Eccho'd the Muſick which the Barges bore;
Riſen from Table ſuddenly did appear
Fire-works o'th Bank-ſide darted in the Air,
And Thouſand Thouſands flying now upright,
And now acroſs did make a day of Night▪
In which Deluge of flames you would admire▪
To ſee th' Element of water turn'd to fire;
This paſt, and done we danced the reſt o'th' Night,
Paſſing the time with infinite delight
Till Day, when I waited on the Ladies home,
And ſo we finiſh'd our Collation.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I muſt needs ſay Sir, you have an admirable faculty in recounting wonders; And Paris as great as 'tis has ſeldome ſeen a Banquet like 〈◊〉 this.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, I was ſurpriz'd, and had only an hour or two's warning to prepare it, elſe that had been far more ſplendious and magnificent.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The order was rare and exquiſit, and the expence muſt needs have been Exceſſive and Immenſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A ſlight Toy not worth the ſpeaking off.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, fare ye well ſir, we ſhall meet another time at more lieſure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I am your Servan •
ſir, and I beſeech you count me ſo.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I even die with jelouſie Philiſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Faith and y'ave ſmall reaſon; for the particulars of this Collation agree but ill with the particulars of the Page.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The hour and place agree at leaſt, the reſt is nothing.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Now Sir, may I freely ſpeak to you, without offence?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thou mayeſt, and thou mayeſt chooſe too whether thou wilt or no: but look, before company you be leſs ſaucy hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Is it your Cuſtome to Reve thus when you talk?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How Reve?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Nay Sir I ſpeak with reſpect unto you; in any other but your ſelf I ſhould call it plain lying.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fool thou haſt no wit.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Faith Sir, for that little I have you'd make me loſe it to hear you talk a this manner, of Wars and Banquets, and conſorts of Muſick, and I know not what: I like you, you fight without any danger yet, and make Feaſts without any Coſt; but why I wonder ſhou'd you fain y'ad been in Town ſo long?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why but the more to endear my affection?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And what had the Wars to do with that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Simple! twou'd have been a fine Complement wou'd it not? to ſay Ladies I am latly come from the Ʋniverſity, and if y'ave any need of the Laws, or of the Rubriques, I know the whole Codex, and Authenticks too; the Old and New digeſt, the infortiat Baldus Jaſon, Accurſius and Aleiat; this brave diſcourſe now would render one very conſiderable in Ladies company and mollifie the Hearts of the moſt inexorable, wou'd it not? and a Paragraph-man wou'd make a fine Gallant for Ladies! no the Title of the Valiant is that introduces us into their favour, ſtrait, and makes them
admire us too; they love Souldiers, and love to hear them talk of Angles, Lines, Fortifications, ſtrange names of Men, Cities and Nations; which the leſs they underſtand more it amazes 'em: All the Art is in ſetting a good Face upon't, Lying handſomly and Swearing with a good Grace.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: But when they know all this is but a Lye?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: When once I've gain'd acceſs by't, what care I; and for any other misfortune, if any importunatly come to trouble me, 'tis but ſaying we ſpeak by Intelligence, this 'tis to make Love a la Mode now.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Theſe are Myſteries too high for me, I underſtand them not; but touching your Feaſt, you'd prove an excellent maker of Romances (without doubt) and never Ʋrganda nor Meluſin with all their enchantments could furniſh a Kitchen half ſo ſoon, nor half ſo well as you have done: I perceive theſe lofty Fictions are natural unto you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I profeſs I take delight when your great Talkers and Tellers of Wonders think to amaze me with Stories they Tell, to make them preſently more wonder at Stories I Tell 'em again thou canſt not imagine the pleaſure I take

l.hi: To turn their own Wonders home
Ʋnto themſelves and ſtrike theſe Talkers dumb.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I doubt not but that ye take great pleaſure in't; but wo'nt this engage you in quarrels ſometime or other?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If't do I muſt diſengage my ſelf as well as I can again, but this idle diſcourſe, has retarded me from ſeeking the Lady:

l.hi: Come Clyton follow me and I'll teach thee more
Art how to live, than e're thou knew'ſt before.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I doubt not of his worth Sir, nor needs there farther commendation; it is ſufficient he is your Son; but yet I ſhou'd appear too greedy and avidous of marriage, (however worthy he were) to take a Husband on credit whom I ne'r had ſeen before: On the other ſide, to admit his Viſits and Courtſhip in quality of a Suiter; ſuppoſe the marriage went not on it wou'd but expoſe me to affronts and deriſion.
sp.l: Wherefore I deſire to ſee him firſt, and ſee him ſo,
As whether the marriage go on or no,
sp.p: It may be no prejudice to my Fame and me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is but juſt and reaſonable, and you declare
your ſelf Clarina, as diſcreet as fair,
In your demand, I'le go fetch Dorant then,
And within this hour return with him agen,
sp.p: and take occaſion to make a ſtand juſt under your window, that you may throughly ſurvey him; mark but his Perſon, Port and Preſence, and you ſhall ſee, though he came but yeſterday a Scholar from the Univerſity few Courtiers have better Air and Meen than he; but of this your ſelf be judge (after common Fame) for me his Father I may be partial in his Commendations, for the deſire I have
sp.l: To ſee him wedded, being my only Son,
And wiſh him Married unto you alone.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You much honour me Sir, in making ſo worthy a choice for ſo unworthy a perſon, and I in confidence of your commendations; have a longing deſire to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: So, without engageing your ſelf you are reſolved to ſee him then.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am Iſabella; but alas! what can I judge of him by ſeeing of him ſo?
sp.l: I ſhall ſee his outward form 'tis true,
But that is nothing leſt I ſee his interior too.
sp.p: our eyes are but flattering glaſſes, to make things appear far fairer than they are; but pleaſing impoſtures that ſhew them without, far contrary to what they are within; and oftentimes we find a noble Preſence with an ignoble mind: Our eyes then are to have the firſt choice ſtill, but not the laſt; and we are not to diſpleaſe them, on pain of our diſquiet, nor to pleaſe e'm ſo again to be wholly rul'd by 'em; finally 'tis more ſafe
sp.l: To believe them when they refuſe,
Then ofTimes when they chooſe;
sp.p: eſpecially in choice of this marriage chain,
sp.l: (May bind us all our lives perhaps to one,
From whom we may have horror and averſion)
sp.p: (which well conſider'd Iſabella ſhou'd make us more fear, than deſire it,) we had need of more faithful Councellors than our Eyes; as for me, being to chooſe a Maſter, I'm reſolved to ſee him before I make choice of him; and ſee him ſo that I may behold both his exterior and interior.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Beſt ſpeak with him than.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But Alcippe wou'd be jealous.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What matter, ſo you have Dorant, whether he be or no?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
No, I have not yet ſo great an indifferency for him to ſet ſo light by his jealoſie, 'tis now a year ſince we were contracted, and's Father's preſence only expected here for final concluſion of our marriage; who makes ſo many delayes, pretending now buſineſs, now danger of
the Ways, from Tours hither; now indiſpoſition, and now unſeaſonableneſs of the time: as I begin, in fine to ſuſpect the delays, and take them for neglect, mean while I'm not in humor to die for conſtancy:

p.hi: Virginity is a commodity will hardly off, if it be kept too long, each hour it abates and diminiſhes of its price; Time won't be dallyed with, Maids are contemn'd when they grow old; and though

sp.l: Nothing's more glorious than a Virgins name,
(Grown ſtale yet) nothing's more a Virgins ſhame.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: And wou'd you forſake Alcippe for another then?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Elſe Alcippe (what ever may befall)
Would make a better husband than none at all.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I'll tell you how you ſhall do then, Lucretia's your friend, and will do any thing for you, get her to ſend a Letter to Dorant to come and ſpeak with her to night, at her window, ſo you may ſpeak with him, under her name, and none be jealous, nor he ever ſuſpect 'tis any one but ſhe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I like th' Invention well, and Lucretia I'm ſure at the firſt word will doo't, so by this ſtratagem I may ſee Dorant and freely converſe with him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Now I think on't, you freely enough to day convers't with that ſtrange Gentleman; and if I ben't deceiv'd, lik't his Converſation▪ too well enough.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And if Dorant's do like me but as well, I ſhou'd have but ſmall difficulty to leave Alcippe for him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Peace don't name him, he comes here.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: His coming troubles me—but go you to Lucretia's and as you have advis'd; I'le leave the manngement of all to you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Ah Clarina, Clarina!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Falſe, inconſtant Clarina!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Has he over heard me? or heard of this intended marriage? what ayl you? you ſigh ſo.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You make as if you did not know! ask of your own Conſcience and that will inform you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Speak ſoftly, my Father comes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your Father comes! falſe-hearted diſſembling Woman, you fear your Father now I am here; but all Night on the River you had no fear at all of him,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What all night on the River? I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Can you ask me withont bluſhing?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What ſhou'd I bluſh for?

sp.speaker: Al,
sp.p: Methinks you ſhou'd even die for ſhame to hear me name theſe two words t'ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What deadly Charme have theſe two words I pray? that I ſhou'd die with hearing them?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Can you hear them and deſire to hear more, or can't you bluſh unleſs I tell you all?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What all?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why all your Revels laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What Revels? hang me if I know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: When I'm with ye, your Father comes, an excellent excuſe! but you can be with others all night and he ne'r thought upon,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why Alcippe are you mad?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Knowing what I know you were enough (I confeſs) to make me ſo; yes all night, untill Morning, I ſpeak of no longer agon, than Yeſter night.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: D'ye Reve? or Rail? or what's the Myſtery?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
The myſtery is ſomewhat new and ſtrange, (I grant you) but
not ſo ſecret as you imagine it; for in fine your Gallant has told me all; you ſee what diſcreet Gallants you make choiſe of.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What Gallant?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dorant.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Dorant!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Tis very good! fain your ſelf ignorant ſtill, do.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: If ever I ſaw him—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And was not his Father here juſt now with you? 'tis well, go on and paſs the Day with the Father, and the Night with the Son, 'tis very well▪

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: His Father and mine are Old Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Al,
sp.p: And was't for that I pray, that he was here? I, now you bluſh, when you know not what to ſay; needs there any more yet to convince you?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: As for his Son, proteſt I never ſaw his Face.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Very likely, but yet however it was night you could not but ſee him by the Fire-works light; or had you no lieſure perchance to look on him for admiring his ſumptuous Feaſt, of ſix Services, and twelve Diſhes at leaſt at every one? Or did the Dancing and Muſick ſo wholly take up your Attention? you cou'd not mind him! yet you might have ſeen him by day at leaſt; for▪ 'twas bright day ere you broke up your Feaſt: have I told you enough yet? to make you underſtand my meaning, and bluſh, and die for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What at a fain'd Story?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Belike I am a Lyar then! a humorous Coxs-comb! a jealous Aſs?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Somebody infallibly has abus'd you—Alcippe credit me,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come, come ne'r ſeek excuſes, I know your tricks well enough, but 'twill not ſerve your turn; farwell, enjoy Dorant, Love him, Adore him, let me alone, and ne'r think of Alcippe more.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But •… ar me a word or two before you go.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, no, your Father comes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: He do's not, I did but jeſt, but ſtay till I've diſabus'd you at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well on condition you inſtantly marry me and give me your hand, and faith, and two Kiſſes to boot, I care not if I do.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And will no leſs do't?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Two kiſſes, no leſs, and thoſe of your kindeſt ones; nay quickly diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I cannot, My Father comes.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.p: Go then, and mock my Anger, do,
sp.l: Make ſport at my rage and me, till with indignity
Thou break my bands and chains, and ſet'ſt me free;
sp.p: turn my deluded fires to Ice; and in their ſtead, let my juſt Anger burn; mean while
sp.l: I'le ſeek your Gallant out, and make him feel
The dire effects of my revengful ſteel;
sp.p: ſhort ſhall be your joy of him, his blood and mine both in one ſtream ſhall run; e'r he ſhall glory in poſſeſſion of any thing was mine—but ſee he comes here, and's Father with him; my gall riſes at ſight of him, and all my friendſhip turns to hate, but this is not a time nor place.

div.head: Scena, 5.
div.stage: Geronte, Dorant, Clyton. The Ladies at the Window moſt part of this Scene.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Stay Dorant, and let's reſt a while, I'm weary and out of breath with walking; and what think you of
sp.l: theſe buildings? are they not fair?
and the Architecture excellent and rare?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Paris appears to me
sp.l: A City of ſome Romance, or Inchanted Ile
I left a Deſart and find ſo built the while,
As if ſome Amphion without Maſons Aid,
Had all its Palaces out o'th quarries made.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Paris every day beholds as ſtrange Metamorphoſes as theſe, to ſee whoſe Temples and Palaces you'd ſwear that Kings and Gods, did only inhabit here: but leaving this Diſcourſe—you know Dorant how much I love you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I do, and am moſt happy in the knowledge of it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: In a word then—Conſidering the danger that youth and honour may dayly expoſe you to, i'th perilous courſe you have taken having no other Son but you to give ſome allay unto your youthful heat, and to prevent that honorable danger I am reſolv'd to marry you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh dear Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And have choſen a Wife for you, both Noble, Rich and Handſome.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I beſeech you Sir take ſome longer Time to conſider on't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: There needs no further conſideration; all Paris affords not a better nor fitter choice than the fair and vertuous Clariſſa; whoſe Father (my Ancient friend) and I have already concluded the marriage—why d'ye look ſo ſtrangely?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas Sir you make me tremble to think o'th heavy weight I'm to under-go, • 're my youthful years have force and ſtrength enough to ſupport the burthen.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Go to, leave theſe excuſes for I'll have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No wayes to prevent it— Aſide. what Sir wou'd you have me marry now e're I've gain'd an honourable Fame by War-like deeds, unto our Houſe and Name?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I marry will I Sir, e're by your War-like deeds you come fairly to be knockt o'th head, I'de have you marry and get an Heir to inherit in your ſtead when you are gone and be a comfort unto me, and ſupport unto our Houſe and Name, d'ye ſee? come ne'r diſpute of't, for I'll have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But what if't be impoſſible Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I humbly at your feet Sir demand your pardon, for I'm—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Being at Poictiers—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Since you'll needs have it Sir, I'm—married already!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How! without my conſent?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You may do what you pleaſe Sir—but I could not help it, I was forc't unto't by the ſtrangeſt accident, the fa •… chance—oh did you but know Sir!—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Tell me and conceal nothing from me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This I can aſſure you Sir, the Gentlewoman is very well deſcended, though not altogether ſo rich as you may deſire perhaps.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: For that we ſhall talk more hereafter; what's her Name?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Orphiſia Sir, and her Father's Armedon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Orphiſia and Armedon! they're names I never heard of—well, on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: At my firſt arrival Sir I chanc'd to ſee this conquering Beauty, who had ſoon reduc'd me to that ſweet Thraldom and amiable Servitude, from which I neither would, nor could be free,
sp.l: Having then no other thought or care
But only of ſerving her,
Six months were ſcarcely gone and paſt,
But by my aſſidual ſervices at laſt,
I gain'd her affection, and was ſo happy to be,
As much belov'd by her as ſhe by me:
sp.p: in which happy ſtate I long continued, till one Night late ('twas the ſecond day of September, I ſhall never forget the day)
sp.l: Harmleſly diſcourſing with her in her Chamber all alone,
Her Father having Sup'd that night abroad came home.
And knock'd at her chamber door; when ſhe
All ſurpriz'd at his coming, having firſt hidden me
Behind the Bed, ran and open'd him the door,
Who ſitting down began to diſcourſe with her
sp.p:
of Marriage, and ſaid he had provided a husband for her; (imagine what ill News this was for me?) In fine, ſhe anſwer'd him ſo diſcreetly as for that Time he was ſatisfied, and juſt bidding her good night, when my Watch ſtrook; at which ſtarting, What Watch is that (quoth he,) or who gave it you? quoth ſhe, my Cozen Acaſte has ſent it me out of the Country to get it mended; quoth he again Let's ſee't, when ſtrait ſhe ran to me behind the Bed to fetch it; when behold the ſtring of it being intangled in the Cock of my Piſtol (I carried ready bent,) off went the Piſtol: when imagine the amazement and aſtoniſhment of all: ſhe all a •… righted
〈◊〉 a ſound, he no leſs frighted ran out, crying
Thieves, and Murther, and preſently return'd again and three or four with him, all withdrawn Swords, when inſtantly drawing mine, I ſoon had made my way through the midſt of them, had not my Sword unfortunatly broke in three pieces; after which ſeeing no other way, I retir'd back again into her Chamber, when ſhe (recovered by this time) out of her care of me, juſt as I enter'd, clapt to the Door, and ſhut them out; when they more furious grown, ſtrait went about to break the door open, and we as faſt within to Barricado it, with Tables, Chairs and Cheſts, and all we cou'd heap againſt it: In fine, this Seige we held out long to gain Time, and reſpit Danger, till at
〈◊〉 breaking down the Wall upon us, I was ta'n all unarm'd and defenceleſs, and fain to come to compoſition with them for my life.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Which was, in plain Engliſh, to marry her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: True • ir—and how could I do leſs taken as I was alone with her by night? The ſcandal great, the danger of her honour and my life moſt evident, and they the ſtronger; but above all, her beauty made more lovely by her Tears;
sp.l: And Love chiefly in that occaſion ſhown
More caref •… of my ſafety than her own,
sp.p: was that which chiefly conquer'd me, and made me yeild, willingly to do that I'de elſe bee • forc'd unto and ma •… ry her ſtrait;
sp.l: So 'voiding danger, and rend'ring all parts content,
To which I humbly here beg your conſent,
My Love and Affection being to her ſo great,
And ſhe ſo every wayes deſerving it,
You muſt reſolve to ſee me married
Unto 〈…〉 or elſe to ſee me dead▪

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Heaven forbid I ſhou'd be ſo hard-hearted and unnatural, eſpecially thou having done nothing but what I ſhou'd have done my ſelf in thy Eſtate • —all that I blame in thee is only t'have ſo long conceal'd from me your Marriage▪

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, I durſt not tell you Sir, by reaſon ſhe was no richer.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Suffices ſhe loves you, and you love her; and if ſhe be ſo well born, diſcreet and fair, as you report her, and have ſuch ſtore of other perfections, ſhe's rich enough and I deſire no more, Farewell▪ I'le to Clariſſa's Father ſtrait and diſengage my promiſe
of marrying you unto his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now Clyton, have I not finely gull'd and cozen'd the Old man, with aſtory of mine own Invention?—ſome fools now, in my Caſe wou'd not have known what to have done, but whyn'd and cry'd and ſuffered themſelves to be married againſt their wills; thou ſeeſt now how neceſſary it is to lye ſometimes to purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And was all this but a Lye then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not a word of it true, but all invented purpoſely to prevent my Marriage with Clariſſa.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: The Watch! the Sword! and Piſtol!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: All, fain'd and only a Maſter-piece of mine own invention.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: For Heavens Love Mr. Then, if ever you'd oblige your poor ſervant, give me ſome ſign hereafter when you go about to lye and play any of theſe Maſter-pieces any more; for though, I know you pretty well, proteſt yet I was deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well never fear, thou ſhalt be ſo no more, I'll make thee hereafter, the Secretary of all my Thoughts, and Cabinet of all my Secrets.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And with all theſe qualities I fear I ſhall hardly keep my ſelf from being deceiv'd by you agen; but touching your Amours Maſter—this Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: With me fair Maid?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pleaſe you read that Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: From Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha!—Kiſs her fair Hand Reads. and ſay I ſhall not fail to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now Clyton! what think you! you had beſt ſay, the Lady I ſpoke withall to day was not Lucretia; behold her Letter here, inviting me this Night to come to ſpeak with her, at her Window, and what has the other to do to write to me, to whom I ne'r ſpoke word?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay, but without more diſpute, have patience only till Night, and you will know by her voice (at leaſt) whether't be ſhe or no.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Mean time▪ go thou as ſecretly as thou canſt and inform thy ſelf of her Birth and Parentage, and what fortune ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Sir. gives him a Note.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What more Letters?

p.hi: Having received an Injury from you I ſhou'd deſire to meet you in the Mail with Sword in Hand.

sp.p: Tell him I ſhall not fail; why this is pretty! I arrived here but yeſter Night, and to day's the firſt ſight of me, yet I've got a Miſtriſs, a Marriage, and a Quarrel already; I want but a Proceſs to make an end of me: Om! I'd forbid any in ſo ſhort a Time, to have more buſineſs on their backs at once, or more difficult and dangerous on's; ſend me good luck with them—but let's go ſee what my old Friend Alcippe wou'd have with me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Y'Ave both done as befits valiant men, and I'm moſt glad it was my happy chance to arrive here in time to part you, and make you friends, whilſt you were on equal terms, and no advantage on either ſide—ſomewhat a rare Adventure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To me I'm ſure it was, who fought with as much Phlegm, as he with Choller all this while, not knowing the reaſon why, which pray Alcippe now declare, that if you have conceiv'd any cauſeleſs jealouſie, or any by falſe reports has injur'd me, I, before him may clear my innocence.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You know it well enough—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: May I periſh if I do, or ever (as I know of) ſaid, or did any thing that might offend you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Since you'l needs have it, d'ye think it was no offence, to have given Ball, Muſick, and Collation, to Night, to a Lady I long had lov'd, and now was juſt on terms to make my wife?—
sp.l: And more to increaſe the injury and diſgrace,
To have boaſted of it too before my face;
sp.p: and how you had lain privately in Town this month, upon deſign only to do me this ſenſible affront: d'ye think all this (now) was no offence?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: See how y'are deceiv'd? and how little reaſon you have for your jealouſie? She I gave a Treat to, is married, and one I'm ſure you never ſaw, lately come to Town on ſome affairs.—Does this ſatisfie you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How was I deceiv'd?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And if I had not given you ſufficient proof of my valour already, and how I fear you not, I ſhould not give you this ſatisfaction now.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: If this be ſo I am moſt glad, our quarel's ended, and the atonement made.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And ſo am I. But let me intreat you Alcippe, hereafter to give leſs credit to your jealouſie, and conſider better what you do before you challenge any one, leſt you begin there where you ought to end; and ſo I leave you, and am your Friend and ſervant.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What, ſad ſtill?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Alas, I'm but recovered from one trouble, to fall into a greater; for who ſhould have given this Muſick and Collation to Clariſſa, if he did not? or who ſhould I call to account for it?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Whoſoever gave it, aſſure your ſelf, Clariſſa was not ſhe 'twas given unto, (as I'm credibly inform'd) but Daphne and Hippolita; and 'twas only your Pages Errour, who ſeeing Clariſſa enter Lucretia's, and ſtrait two Ladys mask'd come out again, take Coach, drive to the River ſide, light and take Barge there, a Collation brought and Muſick too, imagin'd it was ſhe and Lucretia; which being ſo, no wonder your Page, being firſt deceiv'd himſelf, ſhou'd afterwards (as he did) deceive you too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: D'ye think it was no otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I'm certain of't; nay more, am ſure all night ſhe ne'r ſtir'd out of door.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: This more and more troubles me. What a wretch was I then, to quarel and wrangle with her, as I did, for nothing?

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.p: For that I'll make your peace; as for Dorant the Author of all this trouble, who told us ſo many ſtories of his being in Town this month, and viſiting incognito, an incognita, with all the particulars of his ſumptuous feaſt, know he only yeſterday came to Town, and all night too never ſtir'd from home.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And what the Collation?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: All a meer fiction; Or if he gave any 'twas only in a dream.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
It cannot be—Dorant is valiant, as by his brisk anſwer of my challenge in this laſt Encounter, I've experienc'd, and i'th' School of Valour men do not learn to lye; o'th' contrary a valiant man had rather dye▪
than ſuffer ſo foul aſperſion and ſtain to be fix'd upon his Name—wherefore I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Dorant it ſeems is Valiant by Nature, and only a Lyar by Cuſtom; however pray hereafter caſt this jealouſie away, and let us admire our own ſimplicity, cou'd believe a ſtory ſo incredible, that a Collation of ſix Services, twelve Diſhes at every one, four conſorts of Muſick, with Fire-works, and I know not what, cou'd all be provided in an hour or two's time, as if the Collation had been given in ſome of our Theatres, and with machins let down from Heaven. Thoſe who could credit it, had far more faith than wit. I ſaw this Fiction agreed but ill with the Relation of the Page, how the Muſick was but ſo ſo, and the Collation only a Diſh or two: wherefore think no more on't.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: This was my blind jealouſie now, that only ſees with the Eyes of falſe imagination, and believes all true that it imagines: but leaving Dorant with his bold Fictions, I'll to Clariſſa's and ask her pardon.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Better ſtay till to morrow, when I may have made your way, by telling her all this ſtory, and making her laugh again to ſee how finely we were deceiv'd by him. The firſt heat of Choller's always moſt vehement, and 'tis not fit you incurre her full anger, till I before-hand have diſſipated it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And if the uncertain light of the Evening deceive me not, I perceive her coming with Iſabella there. I'll follow your advice then and avoid her ſight till ſhe may have laugh'd at my jealouſie, and pardon it and me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come Iſabella let's go to Lucretia's.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p:
There's time enough, it is not yet ſo late,—Y'are much oblig'd to her; for no ſooner I had told her what you deſir'd,
but inſtantly ſhe diſpatch'd Sabina with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I ſhall be as ready to ſerve her another time. But didſt obſerve how this Dorant Geronte's Son, whom he commended ſo much, is the ſelf-ſame Gentleman we ſaw in the Garden to day?

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: I did, and was much ſurpriz'd at it, and ſo was Lucretia, who mark'd it as well as I▪ And do you continue your reſolution ſtill of ſpeaking with him?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know not—he does ſo lye.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: And is that ſo ſtrange? Dorant is not the firſt young Schollar, who boaſts himſelf a Souldier, and tells you of Battails h'as fought, Sieges h'as been at, though never heard of 'em, but i'th' Gazzette;
sp.l: And forreign Countreys he had travell'd in,
Which (but ith' Map too) he had never ſeen▪
sp.p: to ingratiate himſelf with Ladies; knowing they love men o'th Sword, and love to hear them talk of wars and dangers they had paſt, and like them, when they ſee 'em, make themſelves not what they are, but what they'd have 'em be.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I know not what others are, but I'm ſure he's a Maſter ith' art of lying, and has made Alcippe quite mad with ſtories h'as told him, of muſick and collation given me yeſternight upon the water; judge you what likelihood, or where a word of it is true?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: By this you may perceive how Dorant loves you, and how cunning a Lover he is, who knowing you lov'd Alcippe, firſt did ſet you two at variance, then preſently did get his father, to ſpeak to yours for you; ſo at once gaining the father, and in jealouſing for the nonce your other Lover, to gain you, which he has done in fine, and your marriage is concluded on.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I, as much as ever 'tis like to be.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Won't you obey your father then?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Alas thou art quite wide, and underſtand'ſt nothing I ſee, of what is lately done; he's married unknown unto his father, who poor man came to mine with tears in his eyes, to break off the match betwixt us: now what ſay you of him?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p:
If this be ſo, I'll ſay in my turn too, Dorant is an arrant Lyar, and needs muſt take delight in lying,
who'd make ſuch a lye as this without deſign? For more I think on't leſs I comprehend what ſhou'd be his end in it;—but if this be ſo why will you go and ſpeak with him? is't to chide him, or elſe to laugh at him?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis to tell him ſoundly of it, an't does me good to think how 'ſham'd I ſhall make him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Faith 'twould do me more good to make him ſtarve i'th'cold, and never go.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: No,—I'll go only for curioſity—but ſoft I hear ſome coming, perhaps 'tis he, and through the obſcurity of the Evening he may chance to know me.

I'll to Lucretia's then, and there I may freely ſpeak with him, without all fear of being known, whilſt he'll take me for her,—Alcippe I perceive is like to be the man muſt marry me at laſt, (do what I can) when once he's well cur'd of his jealouſie, which he'll ſo on be when he knows as much as I.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This is the time and place mentioned in the Letter.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Well, I have told you how her Father's one of the long Robe, and ſhe his only Daughter, as alſo what fortune ſhe has, an ancient Servant of the houſe has told me all; and now Maſter, if Lucretia had but a Talent of Lying as wellas you, I ſhou'd of have excellent ſport, to hear you two ſtrive to deceive one another, tell ſtory for ſtory, and pay you in your own Coin, and give you as good as you brought agen, how I ſhou'd laugh?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No Clyton, I'd have thee know
Heaven grants that favour but to few
to lye as I do; they muſt have good memories,
good wits, great care and induſtry;
And finally when they're put unto the puſh
Indeed, come readily off, and never bluſh—
sp.p: but ſoft the window opens—let's draw nigh.

div.head: Scena 5.
div.stage: Clariſſa, Lucretia, Iſabella above, Dorant, Clyton below.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Iſabella ſtand you centinal whilſt I ſpeak with Dorant.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I ſhall, and advertiſe you when any comes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, he recounted all your ſtory to my Father—but ſpeak with him under my Name, and I'll be ſilent the while.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Who's there Dorant?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, Lady, it is I, your humble ſervant, and ſo I'll live and dye.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He goes on in making love to ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: He goes on, with diſſembling I'm ſure on't—I fear he'll know me by my voice.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Well, Maſter, I confeſs y'are in the right this once, 'tis ſhe I'm certain now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis I Lady who willingly would efface out of my lives account, all other days I might have lived, without loving you,
sp.l: Who find living, without ſeeing you, ſuch a pain,
As 'tis not life but rather death again,
sp.p: And ſuch a lingring torment finally,
sp.l: As whoſoever ſuffers, needs muſt ſay,
There's no life but in loving fair Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Hey day! now h'as about with you too; he makes love by turns it ſeems to every one,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He loves to lye to every one by turns I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: In obedience then to your Commandment,
sp.l: I'm come to offer my life here at your feet,
And ſhou'd dye moſt content ſo you'd accept of it.
sp.p: Tell me Lady what you pleaſe to command me now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I thought to ſpeak with you about a certain buſineſs, but now I find it impoſſible—'tis to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How impoſſible? nothing Lady that you command, can be impoſſible for me to do.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Excepting only to marry, for that you can't being married already.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How, I married? Ha, ha, ha! they only jeaſted w'ye that told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Was ever greater impoſtor?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He can do nothing elſe but lye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, far be it from me, and if any—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You think I believe you now?

sp.speaker: Do,.
sp.p: May Thunder ſtrike me dead, if ever I was—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, I know all lyars are prodigal of their oaths.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No Lady, if y'ave any thought of me that may be balanc'd by this falſe report, let it no longer hold you in ſuſpence, of what I can eaſily juſtifie to be true.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To hear how ſeriouſly, and with what aſſeveration he advances a lye, you'd think 'twere true.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To rid you of your doubt Lady, ſo you be pleas'd Ill marry you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And ſo you'd a Thouſand more if they'd believe you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Make but your words good and I ſhou'd be in ſuch reputation here I ſhou'd have thouſands to envy me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: In ſuch reputation (no doubt of it) as he deſerv'd ſhou'd boaſt himſelf ſuch a thunder-bolt of War yet ne'r was there, ſhou'd tell us he had been in Paris almoſt a year a courting Ladies, yet came but yeſterday from Poictiers, who gives Muſick, Collation, and Ball a nights to Ladies onth' water, yet all night at home ſleeps quietly in his bed; and who finally ſayes he's married, and preſently unſayes it again: this is a fine way now to get you credit and reputation! and tell me what's lying I pray, if this be none?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Now Maſter, I'll ſay y'are your crafts-maſter indeed if you come well off here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Fear not Clyton, every thing in its time.—Touching all theſe particulars, Lady I ſhall give you ſuch reaſons hereafter as I doubt not but will fully ſatisfie you. Now to come to the moſt important,—I feign'd this marriage, (for why ſhou'd I make difficulty to confeſs that to you, you muſt needs commend in me) I feign'd it I ſay,
and you blame me for't; but what if you were the only occaſion of't?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray hear me out; the love I bear to you—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Pray maſter tell me if y'are going about to lye or no?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or Ill pluck that ſaucy tongue of yours out of your head—The love I bear to you, I ſay, not permitting my father ſhou'd marry me to any one but you alone—

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: Now he begins to tell a new lye,—hark.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I feign'd this marriage purpoſely to keep my ſelf free from marrying any one but you: now go—and call me Lyar, and Impoſtor, and what you will, ſo you call me your faithful Lover too; and blame me if you pleaſe for this feign'd marriage, ſo by this Fiction I may conſerve me conſtant to you alone.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have reaſon to ſuſpect this love Sir, 'tis ſo hot and vehement at firſt; for how cou'd my eyes inkindle in you ſo great a flame? y'ave ſeen but once and do not know me yet?

sp.speaker: D • r.
sp.p: How, not know you! Is not your Mother dead? Is not your Father's Name Pariander, a grave and ſober Counſellor? was not your Brother ſlain i'th' Wars of Italy? Had you not a Siſter call'd Julia? Now go, and doubt I pray whether I know you yet or no.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now Couzen I ſee plainly 'tis you he means, and you he makes love to.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I would it were. aſide

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But I'll know all before I've done.—Well, Sir, at importunity of ſome Friends I thought to ſpeak with you concerning Clariſſa, and pray tell me, is't true you intend to marry her?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How, I to marry her? beſeech you no more of this; I've diſcover'd t'ye the very bottom of my heart, where you muſt needs ſee I feign'd this marriage only for love of you, for whom I've nothing but affection, as I've nothing but averſion for Clariſſa.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yet let me tell you, Sir, ſhe's not ſo contemptible as you make her, and there are others don't deſpiſe her, though Lucretia ſeems the fairer in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I, ſh'as one main fault though—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, I can't abide her, that's enough,—and for my part I ſwear, I'll be married in Turkie rather than marry her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And yet they ſay you gave her your hand, and courted her very amorouſly to day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who I? no ſuch matter I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: D'ye hear the impoſtor? 'tis a wonder he does not ſwear.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: May Heaven—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Did I not tell you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: May Heaven I ſay, ne'r proſper me, if I ſpoke to any one but you to day.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I can no longer indure his impudence—
sp.l: How dare you deny that and forſwear it too,
Which I my ſelf to day did ſee you do?
sp.p: Hence avoid my ſight, and pray know, I ſent for you only to make ſport with you; who love to laugh and make me ſport ſometimes with better wits than yours, I'd have you know.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Well, you ſee now all's diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I, and I'm almoſt at my wits end with it too.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Mean time you may glory in your good ſucceſs, and how you have gain'd a notable acceſs
sp.l:
Unto your Miſtriſs by't; and if I be
•… e
importunately with my preſence troubles ye,
sp.p: and makes you ſay all this by intelligence now.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Perhaps 'tis only ſo—what thinkſt thou?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I think 'tis a pretty perhaps.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, don't think for all this I'll quit my part of her.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Faith Maſter, if your part of her were to be ſold, and ye chanc'd to meet with a good Chapman for it, I'd counſel you to let him have a good pennyvvorth of this hidden treaſure by any means, hovvever your hopes flatter you to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Wonder! ſhe ſhould give no more credit to my Words yet?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p:
Why, you Lye ſo abominably,
who can believe you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But I told her nothing but the very truth.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I, but when a Lyar ſays it, only paſſing through his mouth, it loſes all its credit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll try then if from anothers mouth ſhe will believe it better, and treat me with leſs rigour hereafter.—Their humours are as variable as the moon, and ſometimes they follow who fly 'em; ſometimes agen. fly thoſe who follow 'em.—Well, I'll to Bed, and take counſel of my Pillow;
sp.l: To morrow 'twill be day.
And nights the beſt counſellor,—let's away.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: WHy Maſter, what mean you to riſe ſo ſoon? they are not up at Lucretia's, it is too early day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No matter, I've choſe this place as moſt proper to reve in, where beholding her window, I may entertain my amorous thoughts, and wholly poſſeſs my mind with her dear Idea▪

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Now you talk of reving Maſter, have you bethought you of a remedy for your laſt diſgrace yet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have, and 'tis the ſame thou taughteſt me yeſterday for ſo ſovereign and approved one, to be liberal enough—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Right, provided you rightly apply your liberality to ſome Coquett or other.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I underſtand, and know Lucretia is too noble and generous to take, or to be ta'en with gifts and preſents: but her Maids have hands and tongues too, that may be untied with Bribes. And howſoever ſhe diaſpprove it, ſhe has Ears too, to hear 'em when they ſpeak; and it ſhall go hard, but I'll gain ſome of 'em, and ſhe who brought me the Letter yeſterday I think the fitteſt; whom I do not doubt to gain if I pay her well for her pains, as I intend.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye maſter, for 'tis my own humour right, to be always moſt kind and complacent to thoſe who give moſt, and count them my chiefeſt friends.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There are enough of thy humour.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: But maſter, in attending Sabina and the operation of our remedy, have you heard the Rumour of Alcippe's Duel?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, with whom?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Some ſay with you; and but I can be anſwerable for you all this day, I ſhould believe it elſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And did not I ſend thee to Lucretia's?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Umh—and waſt for that you ſent me? I begin to ſmell ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes faith 'twas I that fought with him, though I reſolv'd to keep it ſecret; but from thee, the only Secretary of my thoughts, and Cabinet of all my ſecrets, I can conceal nothing. Know then, about ſome five or ſix months ſince we had a quarell at Poictiers, where though we were ſeemingly reconcil'd, there paſt a ſecret Engagement 'twixt us two to fight next time we met; and feigning to embrace we whiſper'd a Challenge into each others ears; when ſending thee away, away we went without any Seconds; and in a paſs or two I quickly diſpatch'd my Gentleman, running him twice through the body and leaving him out of all danger of ever being ſick again, and welt'ring in's gore.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And did you kill him then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Dead, dead, and ſo I left him.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Introth I'm ſorry for't, he was a very honeſt Gentleman. Alack! alack!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dear friend! happily met, I come to make thee partaker of my joy; my father—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is newly arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I thought he had been dead I, thou wert ſo glad; this is a new and extraordinary kind of joy in a ſon like thee, for a Fathers arrival.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I ſhould have told thee (but that a mind wholly preoccupied with joy, imagines every one knows it as well as they) that my marriage with Clariſſa only attended his arrival for its final accompliſhment, and now at laſt he's happily arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How could I imagine this? but I'm moſt glad, and congratulate your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: This place is proper for you to Reve in, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And you'r going thither now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am. and could not but make you participate of the good news by the way.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Y'ave much oblig'd me in't.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: All thoſe you kill'd, Sir, are alive and well you ſee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: So then you fear no farther impediments in your Amours?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How can I? All parties being ſo well agree'd.—.Dear friend, pardon the impatience of a Lover; I've left my father repoſing himſelf after his Voyage, and have ta'en the occaſion to viſit my Miſtreſs the while: farwell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Farwell and may your marriage prove as happy and fortunate as you deſire.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And is this he that's dead? well, Maſter, I did not think you'd have us'd me thus, the only Secretary of your thoughts, and Cabinet of all your ſecrets: but I perceive with all theſe qualities, one ſhou'd have much ado not to be deceive'd by you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Doſt think this combat then was nothing? and only a ſtory of mine own invention?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I can't tell, I ſhou'd be glad to believe any thing rather than diſpleaſe you, Sir, but you invent ſo many every day, and every where, as 'tis a particular grace of heaven if any eſcape being deceiv'd by you: You ſpare none, Turk, Jew, nor Chriſtian, all's one to you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why ſhou'dſt thou think it ſo ſtrange Alcippe ſhou'd be recovered ſo ſoon o'th dangerous wounds I gave him? Didſt never hear of that ſource of life call'd by us Warriours the Sympathetique Powder, that every day works ſuch ſtrange and miraculous effects?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: But none ſo ſtrange and miraculous as this, that a man twice run through the body, and left in the field for dead, ſhould next day appear abroad, all whole, and ſound.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I grant you, your ordinary Sympathetique Powder works none of theſe ſtrange effects? but Clyton, I have the Receipt of making one
vvith Promethian fire, ſhall recall a man from death to life again, in the twinkling of an Eye.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Teach me the Receipt Sir, and I'll promiſe you to ſerve you gratis hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, I will, and make thee rich for ever; but now I think on't the ſecret conſiſts in certain Hebrew Words ſo hard, and difficult to pronounce, as 'twould be a treaſure wholly caſt away upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And can you ſpeak Hebrew then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That I can, and nine or ten other languages beſides.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Faith, and ſo y'ad need, and good ſound ones too, to tell ſo many Lyes: You mince them as ſmall as Herbs to the Pot, and muſt needs be full of verity within, for I never ſaw any yet come out of you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pitty thy ignorance, but ſee my Father here.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O Dorant, I have been looking for you!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But I look'd not for you, what miſchievous luck had I to meet with him aſide.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Conſidering the ſtrait union of marriage, methinks I have not conſented at all to thine, to ſuffer thee to live ſo long from thy wife, and be th' occaſion of ſeperating thoſe Heaven has conjoyn'd; I m thinking then to write to your Father-in-Law, how glad I am to underſtand you'r married to ſo fair and virtuous a Gentlewoman as his Daughter; and how I count our Family highly honour'd, with the alliance it has with his.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Civilities ſir, will much ſurprize him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And ſignifie withall the longing deſire I have to ſee her here; and how I intend to ſend you for her; for to ſend a ſervant wou'd have no grace, and ſhew a want of reſpect and eſteem of her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You may do your pleaſure, ſir, and I'm ready to undertake the Voyage; but 'twill be to no purpoſe, for I'm ſure he wont let her come.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why—ſhe's with Child ſir,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How? with Child!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and at leaſt ſix months gone.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: This is news rejoyces my very heart.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And I'm ſure you would not hazard her miſcarrying, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
By no means, my patience rather ſhall contend with my joy which ſhou'd be greateſt, ha!
with child! Heaven then I ſee has heard my prayer, and I'm moſt happy in't, I'll inſtantly go change my Letter then, and after a few complements, deſire her father to have a ſpecial care of her delivery, as that on which all my happineſs depends.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Poor Man! how glad he is?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Hiſt▪

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And do you write too, d'ye hear? to the ſame effect.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.—Good ſimple ſoul.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: S'lid peace, he comes again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have forgot your Father in Law's Name now, how d'ye call him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, without giving your ſelf that trouble, when you have writ your Letter give it me, and I will write the Superſcription.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Twere better 'twere all of a hand though.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your hand or mine, all's one.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But theſe Country Gentlemen will eaſily take exceptions,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: As for him he has been bred in Court.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, come what need all theſe excuſes & delays tell me his name

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have forgot now. aſide.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: When I ſay?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pyrander, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pyrander! you told me another name yeſterday, and 'twas Armedon now I remember me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Right, Sir, that is his proper name, t'other only of a Signorie he has, by which he was call'd when he followed the Wars, but now, they call him by one and t'other, promiſcuouſly, now Pyrander, now Armedon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Very likely, 'tis a common abuſe▪ warranted by cuſtom that, and I did ſo my ſelf in my younger days: but I'll about my Letter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, now, am I not come handſomly off?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I, but you ſee, a Lyar had need of a good memory.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tuſh, when that fails a good wit ſupplies the want of it.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p:
But the truth of this cannot be long kept hid,
and having taken you tripping once, they'll ſuſpect you at every turn, and Lucretia and Clariſſa know already how y'ave ſerv'd them, who offended at ſo ſenſible an affront, in juſt reſentment of the injury, will cover you all over with ſhame and confuſion in time aſſure, your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Th'haſt reaſon for thy fears, and time putting me to my ſtraits, I'll ſeek preſently to engage my ſelf with Lucretia, and ſee, in good time, her Woman here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Dear Sabina, I was ſo tranſported yeſternight with joy o'th' good news thou brought'ſt me, I had no leiſure to reward thee for't; but thou ſhalt loſe nothing, by my deferring it: hold thee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: O Lord Sir,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Indeed, you do me wrong, Sir, I am none of thoſe.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Beſeech you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I ſay you muſt, and don't think me ingrateful unto thoſe who do me courteſies: there.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: What ado's here with her? out of mere pitty I muſt give her ſome few inſtructions—
sp.l: Hark ye, Sweet-heart, 'twixt you and I,
One of your occupation ſhould fly
This impertinent mincing, mumping, and ſimpering,
Theſe cringes, reverences, and curteſing.
Take what they give you without more ado,
And if one hand ſuffice not ſtretch out two.
For me, when any o'theſe golden ſhowrs do fall,
I uſe to ſtretch out hands, and heart and all;
They take on all hands in this age w'are in,
And only to refuſe is counted ſin.
Care not for fooliſh honour then a ruſh,
One Bird i'th' hand's more worth than two i'th' buſh.—
sp.p: Remember this d'ye hear, and to conclude,
sp.l: To make a friendſhip betwixt thee and me,
If thou art content now I'll go halves with thee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Soft, Sir, that bargain's yet to make.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Look here Sabina, aſſure thy ſelf what I do for thee at preſent is nothing in compariſon of what I will do hereafter, if (as t'haſt done me the courteſie to bring this letter) thou'lt but return me this anſwer back agen.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: That I ſhall Sir, moſt willingly; but whether ſhe'l deign to receive it and read it or no, I cannot promiſe you, but I'll do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: See! ſhe's ſouple as a glove now, and as kind as a young ſimple country Bride.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No matter, give it her, and I'll ſtand to my venture for the reſt; the Ice is broke, and I hope ſhe has no ſuch great averſion from me,—within this hour I ſhall return to know what ſucceſs t'haſt had.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: And by that time, I ſhall be able to reſolve you.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Thou ſeeſt now my Maſter is a Man, whoſe deeds out-go his promiſes; and who makes no more of Gold, then Horſes of Litter which they trample under foot: and I'd have thee know, I can do any thing with him.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why, then, make it rain but more of theſe golden ſhowres, and I'd have you know, I can do any thing with my Miſtreſs too.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Ah Sirrah! thou beginſt to have a feeling of theſe things I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Wou'd you ſhou'd well know, for all my mincing, mumping, and ſimpering, my cringing reverences, and curteſying, I am not ſo ſimple as you imagine me; but underſtand my office, and with my Mumpſimus know to play my Game as well as you with your Sumpſimus, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And if thou underſtandſt thy office ſo well, tell me prethee what hope for my Maſter to obtain his Suit? is thy Miſtreſs ſo inſenſible of his love as ſhe makes ſhew of?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p:
Since your Maſter is ſo honeſt a Gentleman, and ſo liberal withall, I'll tell you, whatever ſhew ſhe makes, ſhe's no ways inſenſible
of his affection; and could hardly ſleep to night for thinking on him, and is half in love with him already, if I be not deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: What the Devil then made her uſe him ſo ſcurvily as ſhe did to Night? or what priviledge has ſhe to uſe her Lovers ſo, more than other women? I like not this love by halves, and wou'd have you know, my Maſter's worth your Miſtreſs at any time; and if he'd follow my Counſel, rather than be us'd a this manner, he ſhou'd even fairly leave her.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Let him not be too haſty though, for I tell ye aſſuredly ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: She has but a harſh way of expreſſing it, though; and for my part, I underſtand not the method of it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You muſt know, ſhe holds a Woolf by the Ears of him (as they ſay) and wou'd fain love him, but dares not for her life, he's ſuch a horrible Lyar; and but yeſterday in the Garden, he told her ſo many Lyes, and to two or three others ſince, as 'tis a ſhame agen.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: But your greateſt Lyars tell truth ſomtimes.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: But ſhe's reaſon to ſuſpect him, knowing him as ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Let her believe him but this once, and believe me, he hath nothing but ſigh'd for her all this Night.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: But don't you lye now as well as your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Fie, that you ſhou'd think ſo?
I'm none of thoſe I would have you to know.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Tell me true then, does he not love Clariſſa?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I tell thee he never did.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Art ſure on't?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Moſt certain.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well then, let him not fear to ſigh for her in vain: for no ſooner Lucrctia ſaw him, but ſhe ſent me preſently to try what I could ſcrew out of him; and if he love her indeed, all will go well enough.—Go then and let me alone, I need no farther inſtruction how to handle the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Farewell then, and take but pains in the buſineſs, and I aſſure thee another golden ſhowre ſhall rain again.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I ſhall make my Miſtreſs a glad Woman with the news I bring; and ſee her here already, ſhe is impatient to know it, and what this Letter ſays here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, and what ſays the Man and Maſter?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why, they both ſay like honeſt men, Madam, and agree in a Tale. As for the Maſter, you may ſee what he ſays by this Letter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let's ſee't,— Reads
Dorant plays the paſſionate Lover here, but he's ſo great a Lyar, I'm not ſo ſimple to believe a word he ſaith.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I believe him forſooth, no more than you, but I believe his Piſtols though.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, has he given thee any?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Ecce ſignum.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And how durſt you take 'em?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I took 'em Madam, to free you from your ſolicitude, and let you ſee he truly loves you; for without loving the Miſtreſs, you may be ſure he wou'd not have been ſo liberal to the maid; and ſo great a liberality beſides does ſhow, he is a Gentleman of a noble ſpirit too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I'll be no hind'rance to your good fortune; but hereafter when you exceed your duty, look you let not me know of it..

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: But what return to him for his liberality?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, tell him I tore his Letter without vouchſafing to read it; nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Ay me! there's an end of my good fortune then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Only (of your▪ſelf) you may add a word or two of comfort, and tell him, 'tis the nature of us Women to be ſoon offended, and ſoon pleas'd again: and above all advertiſe him, when and where he may meet with me; for more aſſurance 'tis neceſſary I ſee him often.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: If you did but know forſooth, how much he ſuffers for you, you'd never doubt of his affection; all this live-long Night he did nothing but ſigh for you.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.p: To qualifie his ſighing, give him a little hope mingl'd with much fear; and moderate it ſo I may not be ingag'd, nor he diſpair.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, now I can aſſure you Dorant is wholly yours, and I have loſt him quite: but that which comforts me in the loſs of him is, Alcippe's Father's arriv'd, and the match concluded betwixt him and I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Y'are rid of a grat ſolicitude and trouble then.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am ſo, and you like to under go it—mean time you'll have a fine catch of him▪ for d'ye know what he ſaid?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Whatſoever he ſaid, I dare be bound for him, body for body now he only ſays the truth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Perchance he may, but 'tis a great perchance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dorant is a Lyar, I know that well enough, but one may continue telling a Lye ſo long, to make one doubt of the truth of it, at laſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, if you love him, look well unto him, be ſure, and make your bargain wiſely, or he'll deceive you elſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay I may believe him without loving him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But th'are ſo near a kin, as who makes us believe they love us makes us believe them worthy of our love, and believing w'are lov'd, and loving is ſo nigh, one paſſes from the one to the other preſently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But curioſity of▪times produces the ſame effect as love.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I'll believe you this once to do you a courteſie.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, come, you make me mad to hear you talk ſo, leave your fiddle faddles and fall roundly to work, or you'll get Husbands as faſt as old wives crack Nuts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mind her not, the wench is fooliſh,—but pray tell me when you encount'red him in the Garden yeſterday, and gave ſuch willing ear to his complements, was it love in you, or curioſity?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Curioſity: mere curioſity,
with intent to laugh afterwards, and make me ſport at all he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Luc.
Cla.
sp.p: I, but there's great difference though betwixt reading ones Letter, and giving ear to 'em; for the one's favour, the other but a civility: but I ſhall be glad if you find your count in him, who in the ſtate I am, have no cauſe to envy you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Beſides know, I've given Sabina order to tell him I tore it▪ without ever reading it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And what needed that? if you read it only out of curioſity?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, but ſuch a curioſity as yours was, you muſt add that too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo; but 'tis time to go to the Temple.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let's go then.—And do you hear? do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Ne'r fear, this is not the firſt time I've been imploy'd in theſe affairs: I know both your Ma ladies, and't ſhall go hard but I'll apply to either a convenient remedy; but know he's not a man to be delay'd & dally'd with.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: For you my Friends, come you along with me, ſpeaking to her mony
I hope ſhortly to get you more company.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: THis following the Law is a troubleſome buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And why then did you not write to me to diſpatch it for you? I know, beſides the trouble, one of your years muſt needs expoſe his health, as well as eaſe, to much inconveniency, in ſo long a voyage as from Poictiers hither.
But ſince y'are here, I hope to let you ſee, I want not friends, nor power to ſerve you; mean time, tell me I pray of what Fortune and Condition is Pyrander there?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Pyrander, who's that?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One of the principall'ſt quality in Poictiers (they ſay) though none of the wealthieſt.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I know none ſuch in all the Town.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You may know him better perhaps by his other name of Armedon.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I know neither the one, nor the other.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Perchance you may know him better yet by being Father to Orphiſia, ſo celebrated for her rare perfections, and the only admir'd Beauty in all thoſe parts.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Believe me, Pyrander, Armedon, and Orphiſia too, are Names unheard of, and wholly unknown to us; and if you'll not believe me, I'll bring hundreds more beſides my ſelf, to witneſs it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, come, I know you diſſemble with me now, and feign your ſelf ignorant, thinking to do my ſon a courteſie: but I know all, how he lov'd Orphiſia, how he woo'd her long, and at laſt by occaſion of's Piſtols going off, was taken in the Chamber with her, and forc'd to marry her; I know all this, and have forgiven him, and given my conſent to his marriage too, wherefore you need not make it a Secret to me any longer.

sp.speaker: Ar.
