sp.p: I'll lay my life now, ſome body, to do ill offices betwixt you, has invented this Chymerical ſtory, names and all: I know Dorant more valiant and more advis'd than to be ta'en ſo tamely in ſuch a Trap as this; wherefore I pray, believe not theſe falſe Reports.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I can hardly yet believe 'em falſe, being told of't by one aſſur'd me it was true, and knew it was indifferent unto me. But pray in what Reputation was Dorant whilſt he liv'd with you?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Why, he had always the repute of one who had both courage and wit enough; and both ingenious, bold, and reſolute; and one (in fine) cou'd eaſily be Artificer of his own Fame, and make it what he wou'd only one fault he had.—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray what was that?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Why, 'twas a little unſafe to believe him on his word, he took ſuch delight to deceive the world, but 'twas a fault imputed to his youth, and cuſtom of ſuch young Scholars as himſelf, but I hope he would leave that vicious craft, and unhandſome divertiſement, by your example and advice, when he came to riper years, which leſt he does, I can aſſure you 'twill much blemiſh his Fame and Reputation.
But I muſt take my leave, my buſineſs calls me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And may you find that ſucceſs in it which you deſire.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Was there ever a more unfortunate Father than I? who now plainly ſee my Son's a • ourbe and Lyar: And with his Lyes has not only deceiv'd me, but made me his inſtrument of deceiving others.

O ſhame of my too eaſie credulity, and my gray hairs! as if 'twere not enough for me to live with my own ſhame, but I muſt dye guilty of his infamy? he abuſes my goodneſs with a ſeign'd ſtory of his Adventures, & Marriage with not a word of truth in't.
sp.l: Could I but meet with him, I'd make him know,
What 'tis to abuſe his aged Father ſo.
sp.p: O Sir, are you here!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What ill luck had I to meet him?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come hither, and pray tell me, are you a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: I hope, Sir, none doubts it, being born of you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And d'ye think that ſufficient?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I do ſir, and ſo does all France too.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And don't you know with all France, from whence this Title of Honour takes its origin? And that 'tis Virtue only enables us with that Nobility is afterwards deriv'd unto our Blood?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of that which all the world knows, that 'tis Virtue firſt acquires it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And if't be ſo, and contraries always work contrary effects, it clearly follows that as Virtue gives Nobility, ſo Vice does tak't away.
sp.l: Which being ſo, howe'r thou art my ſon,
yet doing as thou doſt, thou art no Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Peace, and hear me. Whoſoe'r does any diſhonourable Action, and after calls himſeif a Gentleman, lyes when he ſays it, and is no longer one; eſpecially lying as thou doſt. Can therebe any Vice more diſhonourable for a Gentleman, born unto Honour, than to tell a Lye? The very name and mention of which ſets ſuch a laſting blot and ignominious ſtain upon his Honour, as but in's life-blood can ne'r be waſh'd out again, and thou be imputed abaſe infamous Lyar?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I! who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Who told me? tell me if thou canſt thy wives name now, with the whole ſtory of your marriage, you told me yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Tell him you have forgot it in your ſleep.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Or elſe your Father-in-Laws name, and's Signorie, and add to your impudence and Effronterie ſome other ſtories elſe to couzen me.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Now Maſter or never make uſe of your memory and invention.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Mean time I (old as I am) was ſo fooliſh to believe you (I ſpeak it to my ſhame) and am become the fable and mockery of every one, for my credulity. But tell me now, thou impudent Lyar, did I uſe any violence or force thee to't? did I ſet a Dagger to thy Heart to make thee wed Clariſſa? If thou hadſt no mind to her, why didſt not tell me ſo?
sp.l: Con'dſt think I wou'd deny thee my conſent
To marry any might be to thy content?
sp.p: I denied thee not (thou ſeeſt) to marry a mere ſtranger? when truth (then) each might have prevail'd with me, what neceſſity was there to abuſe me with a Lye?
sp.l: Methinks this exceſſive goodneſs of mine at leaſt
Shou'd have a little touch, and move thy Breaſt,
Ungrateful as thou art? but now I ſee
Thou haſt no reverence, love, nor fear of me;
sp.p: Hence, avoid my ſight—I here diſclaim thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Good Father hear me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What! more Lyes and new deceits?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, but perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Was ever any in thy mouth?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Beſhrew me, there he touches you home Maſter, how you'll defend your ſelf I know not.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hap'ning to ſee the fair Lucretia, (I'm ſure you know her) at firſt ſight of her,
sp.l: I was ſo taken, 'twas impoſſible for me
Ever to get looſe from that ſweet Captivity.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: On—I know her well, and her Father is my Friend,—but look you do not lye.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And that will be very hard for him to do.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: After which the very name of Clariſſa, and all women too beſides becoming odious to me, I feign'd this marriage only to avoid the marrying her; (not knowing that feigning in Love was any Crime) nor durſt I tell you of it, till I might know whether Lucretra's Birth and Fortunes were anſwerable to your deſire: which now finding both noble and competent I dare, with more confidence beſeech you, Sir, by all the ties of Love and Conſanguinity may bind a Father and a Son, you'd ſecond my deſire, and give your conſent that I may marry her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You'll deceive me once again?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If you wo'nt believe me, believe Clyton here, who knows all my ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Methinks thou ſhould'ſt even die for ſhame,
sp.l: That I thy Father ſhou'd more credit one
That's but his ſervant, than thee his ſon.
sp.p: But that thou mayſt ſee my paternal love to thee, and how good I am, once more (ſpight of my anger) I'll try thee, and hazard again the being once more deceiv'd. I know Lucretia well, and will demand her of her Father; but if afterwards I find the leaſt impediment on thy part—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For more aſſurance I'll go along with yon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, do not; do not follow me; once more I'll try thee, though I miſdoubt thee ſtill: and if thou doſt deceive me, look thou flie my preſence, for by this heavenly light,
sp.l: (Remember my Oath) and yon bright ſun that ſhines,
Thou ne'r ſhalt dye by other hands than mine.
sp.p: Remember.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! theſe threat'nings fright me not.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Faith Maſter, you yielded too ſoon then, and ſhou'd have ſtood out a little longer, if you had any courage in you, and deceiv'd him the third time; there's good luck in odd numbers, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Peace and leave your fooling or you'll anger me. I'm not i'th' humour now, but am troubl'd in mind.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Perhaps 'tis for having told Truth this once. If this of your love to Lucretia ben't a Lye too; for I begin now to ſuſpect every thing you ſay, and know you ſo well, I underſtand you by contraries.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, no, thy ſuſpicions are vain, for I love Lucretia; love her heartily; but that which troubles me, is to think of the hazard I run by declaring my love ſo ſoon? for if her father ſhou'd deny her I'm utterly loſt, and ſhipwrackt in the port; beſide, who knows where ſhe'll continue conſtant.? But that which chiefly troubles me (to tell thee true) is to have ſeen one with her ſo charming fair, as now I better conſider her, it grieves me to have given my heart away before; and if 'twere to do again, I ſhould not know whether o'th' two yet I ſhould give it to.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Why then were you ſo earneſt to have your Father demand Lucretia for you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pho, he would not have believ'd me elſe.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: So, upon the matter you told him a Lye, even when you thought you told him true.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There was no other way to appeaſe his anger. But miſchief on him for me that diſabus'd him, I might have had time and leiſure enough to have conſider'd who t'have choſen of the two.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: And you know that other (Lucretia's boſom friend and inſeparable companion) is no other than Clariſſa?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why then I have done my ſelf a good office, though it troubles me, and I envy Alcippe's happineſs; but my comfort is he has but my leavings, and ſo I'll leave the thought of her.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: As eaſily it ſeems as you did Orphiſia's.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Let's go then and reſtore Lucretia the ſame inviolable faith ſhe had before, and in good time behold Sabina.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What haſt done with my Letter? haſt thou deliver'd it to her fair hands?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I have Sir, but—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What but?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She tore it all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What, without reading it?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I Sir,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And vvou'dſt thou let her?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Alaſs, Sir, I could not help it; ſhe has ſo rated me for't, 'tvvould have pi •… ied ye to hear it: and has turn'd me avvay upon't; I'm quite undone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She'll take thee again ne'r fear it, mean time there's ſomvvhat to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: See! ſhe's at her Reverences again, and hovy ſoon ſhe's comforted?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt to her again, go, I've not loſt all my hopes yet, and did ſhe tear my Letter ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, ſhe bid me tell you ſo; but to deal ingenuouſly with you—

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: This is no cunning Quean!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She did not, but read it all over, vvhy ſhou'd I hold ſo brave a Gentleman longer in ſuſpence?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: If there be a Cunninger betvvixt this and Rome, I'll go thither barefoot.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why then by this account ſhe does not hate me?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, no!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But does ſhe love me?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's ſtrange? does ſhe love any other;

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Much leſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What then may I hope for from her?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay, I knovv not.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come prethee tell me.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What ſhould I tell you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, the truth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I have told it you already.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Dos't think ſhe'll ever love me?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But vvhen?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: When ſhe believes you, not before.

sp.speaker: Dor.
Sab.
sp.p: Peace. Here ſhe comes, and Clariſſa vvith her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
Dor.
sp.p: Admirable Beauty, who only can diſpoſe of all my happineſs and unhappineſs.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: One wou'd think he ſpoke to me, his Eyes are fixt upon me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He glanc'd them on you by chance (perhaps) or ſo, but his words were directed unto me: let's obſerve him farther.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas! in your abſence, in what a mighty pain was I, and how by dear experience now I find to be but a moment abſent from thoſe we love, is an age of torment to a lovers mind.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Still he continues!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But ſee what he writes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But hark what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You take what he ſays to me, as ſaid unto your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee that.—Do you love me then Dorant?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, is my love become then ſo indifferent a thing t'ye, ſince I was wholly yours, you ſhould queſtion that now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: D'ye mark? What think you now? Is this diſcourſe directed unto you or me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But let's hear out the whole impoſture.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a little groſs, conſidering what we know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I do not like this whiſpering,—beſeech you Lady, whatever ſhe ſays unto you believe her not; conſulting of my Life and Happineſs, admit more favourable Councellors than ſhe, who has ſome reaſon I grant to have a pique againſt me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have but too much indeed, and if I don't revenge me—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomewhat ſtrange indeed, what ſhe has told me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Believe her not I beſeech you, 'tis only ſome invention of her jealous thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I believe ſo,—but in fine, are you ſure you know me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Know you! pray no more of this Railerie. Are not you ſhe, I had the Honour yeſterday to entertain in the T •… uilleries, and who ſince I've made the abſolute Miſtreſs of my Heart?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Which y'ave ſince given away to another, if I may believe her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I given it away unto another! rather let me die here at your feet, your angers ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay more, ſhe ſays y'are married to another too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! nay, now I ſee, you ſay all this (indeed) in Railerie to make you ſport, and here me often repeat again, and again, that I am only yours.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And that you ſaid, before you'd be married to me, you'd be married in Turkie.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I, and if they pleaſe in Argier's too, before I'll marry any one but you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And that y'ad nothing but Averſion for Clariſſa.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come, come, what need this? you, know the whole Myſterie of it? and that I do all I can to marry you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I can't tell what to think of 't now my ſelf.—Hark ye Lucretia?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How! ſhe Lucretia?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Oh! are you advis'd of that now? did I not tell you ſo? and you'd not believe me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: It cannot be, I'm ſure I knew her by her voice to Night.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: You were deceiv'd; 'twas Clariſſa ſpake t'ye under Lucretia's Name, Sabina has told me all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I! was't ſo, well, ſay no more, keep my Counſel, and thou ſhalt ſee how handſomly I'll come off; and without changing diſcourſe, only change battery, and in a quick turn make all good again. I began to find her handſome before, and had a ſecret inclination to love her, which now I'm fully reſolved to do; and ſo that was my Error, ſhall be my Judgment too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now put him to his laſt Teſt of his impudence, and ſee how confounded, and aſham'd he'll be.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, Sir, in a word, ſhe, as my Friend, has told me, how you courted her to Night, and how you ſlighted me. Pray who is't of us two that is deceiv'd? for one it needs muſt be; and you ſpoke to her ſo lovingly and amorouſly to Night it makes me think 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who I! proteſt I ne'r ſpoke to any one but you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And did you not ſpeak to Lucretia then to Night?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! as if I did not know you by your voice▪

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I think at laſt he will begin to tell truth indeed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
You would fain put a trick upon me, and I let you go on to be reveng'd of you, and feign'd I did not know you. But alas, alas, d'ye think I was ſo ſimple? the deceit was too groſs, and pray learn againſt another
time to chooſe better by their Phyſiognomies, thoſe you'd put tricks on, for I am none of them.—You thought to deceive me, and I deceiv'd you; only my
• lightings of you were feign'd to be reveng'd on you. For in fine I love you, and ſhou'd hate my life if any moment of it were ſpent in any thing, but only in ſerving you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And if this be true, why did you feign yourſelf married when you ſhou'd have married me? I do not ſee what end you could have in that?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Or why wou'd you w • ite me this Letter if 'twere not for love of me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How I love the hidden cauſe of this anger now? that needs muſt be the love of me, ſince y'are diſpleas'd at my loving her; wherefore having enough diſſembl'd, I here declare, faireſt Lucretia, 'tis you I love, not her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Was there ever a greater Impoſtor? how can you indure to hear him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Stay, and when y'ave heard me out, you can no ways doubt of the truth of that I ſay. Underſtanding of Clariſſa's intent to Night, under your Name to deceive me; and how you were conſenting to it too: to revenge me gently on you, I ſaid ſomething I grant that might have offended you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But what ſaid you yeſterday in the Thuilleries?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Complements 'tis true, were to Clariſſa, but my heart to you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Out upon him! can you have any patience to indure him longer?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And there 'twas your fair eyes kindled that fire in me; I durſt not let appear, till I might ſee whether my Father wou'd approve my flame or no: And as all the reſt of my diſcourſe to her was only feign'd, ſo that I told her of my being ſo long in Town, and coming from the Wars, was a mere Fiction too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: D'ye mark how he goes heaping Lyes upon Lyes, and does nothing but juggle with us?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: In fine, dear, dear Lucretia, you are ſhe alone to whom I have dedicated all my affection.

sp.speaker: Lu •…
sp.p:
Your actions ſo little confirm your words as I ca •
• carce believe 'em.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But if my Father be gone to demand you of your Father, will you believe me then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: After ſo clear a Teſtimony as that, I ſhould conſult my ſeriouſer thoughts perhaps whether I ſhould or no.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I doubt not then, but ſhortly you-will ſee theſe clouds of doubt all diſperſt and diſſipated by the light o'th' verity. Mean time Clariſſa, betwixt you and I, love your Alcippe, who had had no part in ye, but for my feign'd marriage. But this he ſhall never know for me; and ſee where he comes here.

div.head: Scena 8.
div.stage: Alcippe and Geronte ſeveral ways, Lueretia, Clariſſa, Sabina, Dorent, Clyton.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Our Parents are agree'd, and Clariſſa you are mine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And as for yours fair Lucretia he has conſented Dorant ſhou'd marry you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Leaſt ſign of your hands then, the buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And as for you, leaſt words of your mouth, will do the buſineſs too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sweeteſt, deny me not that happineſs.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What are they both dumb? that they hold their peace.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Father, in fine, may abſolutely diſpoſe of me.

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.p: And I am all obedience unto mine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come then and prove the ſweet effects of his Commandments.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And you, that of yours,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Now y'are married, farewell my golden days. You have no need of my office any more.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fear not, I'll be more liberal then e'r I was before.

lg.l: To Lye is nothing, but do it ſo dextrouſly,
As not to be intangled in a lye,

There's the Art of it; and I'll forbid any
• ne,
To do it ſo dextrouſly as Dorant has done.
And thoſe who will not fail in the dexterity,
Let them come often here, and learn to lye.
